issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: Signifies completion of tasks, info requests, etc.
resolution.name: Completed

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description:
On the QA's POC environment where the proxy is running on the machine as the CLC, it was seen that the memory usage of the proxy continuously increased and reached near 4 GB after 5hours:

7725 root 20 0 5681m 3.9g 4512 S 1.3 50.2 11:36.53 python

, which is about 50% of the memory capacity of the machine.
fields.summary: After running for 5 hours, the proxy's memory usage goes near 4 GB.

comments.body: I'm attaching some Dowser output from about 1.5 hours of run time on the proxy. Memory has held steady not going above 1.2GB on OS X. I know that memory on OS X seems to be lower than (say) centos. Of course there may be differences between python 2.6 and 2.7 (2.6 being the default on CentOS, and 2.7 being what I have installed on my mac).

This file (Dowser_Types_3) shows results for a similar experiment to the previous, but with the proxy running on CentOS (vs OS X). Along with this, I'm seeing real memory peaking at about 2GB. Virtual holding stead at about 3.7GB, a figure I couldn't see on OS X's activity monitor.

[~dkavanagh] to try to debug this via dev cloud with Dowser running for a longer time and attached to AWS. Will determine if we can find a root cause and then see if this is something we can/should fix for 3.4.1 or push to 4.0 when cache management will be better and might mitigate this issue.

Checking a few hours later, memory usage dropped a little, but still pretty high.

 8332 root      20   0 5799m 3.7g 3436 S  2.0 47.8 189:35.48 python
ECC CPU Graph reported by Dan

Dan has learned of the CPU slowdown issue on ECC due to what seems to be related to this ticket.

See the graph in the attachment.
The CPU issue is now under control, but there is still memory usage that grows over time. I've not been actively pursuing this issue.

[~neil] and I talked and we're going to take the approach we did in 4.0 to help mitigate the memory issues. The approach is to never fetch the full image set and to add a text field to allow users to specify an image ID when it doesn't appear in the image picker. It doesn't fix the memory issue (which is a tricky python GC thing), but does help mitigate the problem.

Complete the re-work. Instead of fetching 20K+ images, slightly less than 3K images are fetched.

https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucalyptus-console/pull/254
The snapshot test was failed. When checked manually, it was verified that the current image landing page fails to display any snapshotted images.

When examined the pull request, it was seen that a substantial amount of changes went in in the code. 

I would talk to [~alice] for detailed test plan to ensure no regressions have occurred.
looking at ebs image issue.

I was really scratching my head on this one since reverting to maint/3.4/testing allowed me to see all images again.
I felt like this might be a latent bug that got triggered by the changes in this branch. I've traced it back to this commit;
https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucalyptus-console/commit/5433d7ccea61d32fd6a3f94898e9d719e0b49906
I've made a small alteration in that commit and now see all images again. It was zeroing out the images collection in certain conditions. Now, I have an endless fetch loop going on, so I'll have to look at the original bug that caused that commit to re-evaluate the fix.

looks like 2 things at play here.
In current maint/3.4/testing, I can't use owner:me search unless I first get security groups loaded.
I've fixed the owner:me facet problem in the maint/3.4/testing code (but will include the fix in the EUCA-8162 branch changes)
I found 2 problems, one from before, and one from this branch. Finally!!
The fix has been merged. Verified that it passed the automated test. Didn't get to verify any special, corner cases.
More thorough testings, such as AWS image testing, load testing, stress testing, etc, would be required for this ticket.
Thanks, Kyo! Will pull in the new packages and start thorough testing.
Ran load testing/stress testing on AWS and Eucalyptus.
